keyTakeAways: Iceland, long considered mosquito-free due to its cold climate, has confirmed the presence of its first wild mosquitoes — three individuals of the Culiseta annulata species — found in Kiðafell, Kjós, near Reykjavík.
The discovery marks the first known occurrence of mosquitoes in the natural environment of Iceland, unlike a previous isolated finding in a plane at Keflavík Airport.
Culiseta annulata is native to the Eastern Hemisphere, ranging from North Africa to northern Siberia, and is adapted to cold climates by surviving winter in sheltered areas.
Theories suggest the mosquitoes may have arrived via ships or containers, though their exact origin remains unknown.

While climate change may have contributed to warmer conditions allowing mosquitoes to survive, scientists remain cautious about directly attributing the discovery to climate change, noting that mosquitoes have been found in other northern regions and that the full impact of warming on mosquito ranges is still uncertain.
Experts emphasize the need for further monitoring in spring to determine whether the species can survive winter and establish a permanent population in Iceland.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Iceland, long considered free of wild mosquitoes due to its extreme cold, has confirmed the first natural occurrence of the Culiseta annulata mosquito species in Kiðafell, Kjós, near Reykjavík. The discovery, made by resident Björn Hjaltason in late October 2025 and verified by entomologist Matthías Alfreðsson, marks a significant ecological shift. While climate change may have facilitated warmer conditions allowing such cold-adapted mosquitoes to survive, experts remain cautious, noting that similar species have been found in other northern regions and that the full implications of warming on mosquito ranges are still unclear. Further monitoring is needed to determine whether the species can establish a permanent population in Iceland.
title: Iceland Just Found Its First Mosquitoes
